Graphical abstract The efficient conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) to the valuable chemicals is of great significance but the development of robust catalyst is still an interesting and challenging issue. Four novel ionic liquids are facilely synthesized with the ability to adsorb carbon dioxide (CO2). [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] and [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] could catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 into cyclic carbonates under atmospheric pressure at 50 °C with 99.3 % and 97.5 % yields in the absence of co-catalyst and solvent. Moreover, the [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] could be reutilized by 11 times with a slightly decreased product yield. A new mechanism is proposed by the density functional theory (DFT). The excellent catalytic performance is mainly attributed to the ability of ionic liquids to adsorb CO2. After the CO2 is adsorbed, the formed intermediate would push the electrons towards the Br- anion leading to the stronger nucleophilic activation. This work introduces a new pathway to explore the ionic liquids for the chemical fixation of CO2. Keywords Carbon dioxide Ionic liquid Homogeneous catalysis Reaction mechanism 1 Introduction Owing to its prominent feature of nontoxicity, abundance, non-expensive, and recyclability, tremendous attention has been focused on the utilization of carbon dioxide (CO2) as a C1 building block to produce the valuable chemicals [1–4]. It is of great significance for the green chemistry and reducing the adverse influence of CO2 on the climate [5,6]. The coupling reaction of CO2 and epoxides is promising from both the view of atomic economy and the wide applications of cyclic carbonates that is the important intermediate to produce polymers and fine chemicals [7–9]. Additionally cyclic carbonates can be directly used as benign polar solvents for application in organic synthesis or as liquid electrolytes in lithium batteries [10–12]. The effective catalytic systems are necessary to be built to overcome the thermostability and kinetic inertness of CO2. Various homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been developed including alkali metal salts [13], organic catalysts [14], MOF [15], metal-salen complexes [16], and so on [17–21]. Yao et al. applied a metal-based complex for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides without any solvent or co-catalyst. The 99 % product yield is achieved at 25 °C under 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure during 18 h [22]. Although the MOF, metal-salen complexes, and metalloporphyrins exhibit the excellent activity for the title reaction under the benign conditions, they suffer from the toxicity, complicate synthetic process and high cost [15–23]. Ionic liquids (ILs) become the ideal candidate because of the negligible vapor pressure, good thermostability, and easily tunable structures [24]. Although numerous ionic liquids have been developed in past decades, the harsh reaction conditions, low activity, or long reaction time are still required to be refined [25,26]. Some task-specified ionic liquids integrated with the OH, COOH and NH2 groups are reported to afford the strong electrophilic group and hydrogen bond donor (HBD) [27,28], which facilitates the ring-opening of epoxides that has been determined to be the rate-determining step [29]. However, only the slight improvement is achieved as compared with the ionic liquids without these functional groups. Recently, two promising developments are emerged. Han et al. [30] have reported a novel dual-ionic liquid ([TMGH+][−O2MMIm+][Br−], ILH) attaining 84 % yield at room temperature under 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure without any solvent and co-catalyst. The excellent activity is attributed to the synergistic effect of CO2 capture and electrophilic/nucleophilic activation along with the hydrogen bond interaction [31]. Later, a complicate bifunctional protic ionic liquid is reported by Zhang et al., which can catalyze the coupling reaction of CO2 and epichlorohydrin (ECH) leading to 92 % yield of chloropropylene carbonate (CPC) at 30 °C under 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure [32]. They assigned the excellent catalytic activity to the strong electrophilic activation of protic hydrogen atom in cation. Inspired by previous studies, a series of novel dual-ionic imidazolium ionic liquids have been facilely synthesized by Wang et al. [31], which exhibits the satisfied activity for the conversion of CO2 ([TMGH+][−O2PHIm+][Br−], ILW). Although ILW and ILH have the similar structures, the reaction mechanism is totally different. The CO2 adsorption play the critical role in promoting the reaction. To further explore the influence of CO2 adsorption on the catalytic activity, a series of novel ionic liquids are easily synthesized by neutralization reaction at room temperature (See Scheme 1 ). They are called the “responsive” ionic liquids indicating that they could give a response to adsorb CO2 when the CO2 moves towards them [33]. [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] and [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] are firstly employed to catalyze the coupling reaction of CO2 and ECH without any co-catalyst and solvent. Over 95 % CPC yield is achieved at 50 °C under 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure indicating their great catalytic activity. The catalytic mechanism and contribution of each part is thoroughly investigated by the density functional theory (DFT)-based calculations. It is expected that this work opens a new pathway to design the robust ionic liquids, which is promising to be applied in other reactions of CO2 fixation. The experimental and theoretical details please see Supporting Information. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Characterization of ionic liquids The four synthesized ionic liquids (See Scheme 1) are characterized by 1H and 13C NMR spectra, elemental analysis, mass spectrum (MS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. The NMR and FT-IR spectra are presented in Figs. S1-S8. The corresponding data are listed in the supporting information along with the elemental analysis and mass spectra data. The CEEPzBr and [BZTMA+][OH−] are also characterized by the NMR, which are listed in the Supporting information. Above data indicate that the target ionic liquids have been successfully synthesized. The structure of [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is further measured by the XPS spectrum (See Fig. 1 ) to testify the involvement of Br− anion. The C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, and Br 3d peaks are all included in the full survey spectrum. In C 1s high-resolution spectrum, there are four characteristic peaks at 287.1, 285.9, 285.5, and 284.6 eV corresponding to CO, CN, CO/CN, and CC/CH bonds. They are contributed by the pyrazole ring, COO− group, and alkyl chain. Three peaks at 402.7, 402.1, and 401.5 eV in N 1s spectrum are attributed to the NN, CN, and CN bonds indicating the involvement of pyrazole ring and benzyltrimethylammonium group. The CO and CO bonds in COO− group are designed to the peaks at 531.7 and 530.1 eV in O 1s spectrum. The 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 states of Br element are confirmed by two peaks at 68.1 eV and 67.1 eV, respectively. According to the above characteristic data, the ionic liquid is synthesized with the expected structure. 2.2 Catalytic performance The common pyrazolium-based ionic liquid, CEEPzBr, only displays the low activity at 50 °C and 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure (entry 2 in Table 1 ). In contrast, the dual-ionic pyrazolium salt, [TMGH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−], contributes the very high yield of CPC under the same conditions (entry 3 in Table 1). The excellent activity is designed to the multiple electrophilic/nucleophilic active site along with the ability of CO2 adsorption of COO- group. To explore the influence of [TMGH+], another similar ionic liquid, [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] (entry 4 in Table 1), is synthesized keeping the Br- anion and [−O2EEPZ+] group, which displays the comparable catalytic activity with the product yield of 99.3 %. Therefore, the Br- anion and [−O2EEPZ+] play the critical role in promoting the reaction, in which Br- anion is taken as the nucleophile and [−O2EEPZ+] is employed to trap CO2. To further clear their contribution, [BZTMA+][Br−] (entry 6 in Table 1) and [BZTMA+][Im−] (entry 8 in Table 1) are developed to catalyze the title reaction. [BZTMA+][Br−] still keeps the relative high activity with the product yield of 85.4 % under the same condition. In contrast, the product yield was reduced to 60.1 % with [BZTMA+][Im−] as catalyst. Therefore, the strong nucleophile is more crucial to enhance the activity as compared with the ability to capture CO2. Although [BZTMA+][Im−] has been testified to be able to capture CO2 [34], the absence of strong nucleophile limits its activity. However, all of them are inferior to [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] indicating that the introduction of group to trap CO2 is an efficient pathway to refine the performance along with the strong nucleophilic activity. To further improve the activity, another ionic liquid, [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] (entry 9 in Table 1), is synthesized, in which [DBUH+] is the more excellent electrophile than [BZTMA+]. Unfortunately, [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] presents the slight inferior activity with the yield of 97.5 %. As shown in Fig. S9, the protic hydrogen atom in [DBUH+] has the more positive charge with the deeper red colour than that in [BZTMA+] indicating the stronger electrophilic ability. However, the overall catalytic activity of [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is the less than that of [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−]. The protic hydrogen atom in [DBUH+] is favorable to form the strong interaction with Br− anion, which shows blue colour in Fig. S10. For [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−], the interaction between [BZTMA+] and Br− anion is the weaker with the green color. The strong interaction between [DBUH+] cation and Br− anion weakens the nucleophilic activation of Br− anion resulting in the slight inferior activity. Therefore, the suitable combination of cation and anion is the more important to achieve the desired goal rather than simple sum of each strong part. Both [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] and [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] display the excellent catalytic activity under benign reaction conditions than most of previous reported single-component ionic liquids, which are listed in Table S1. Other two similar ionic liquids, [BZTMA+][Cl−] and [BZTMA+][I−] are also applied for this reaction to explore the nucleophilic ability. The catalytic activity decreases in the sequence: [BZTMA+][I−] (90.5 %) > [BZTMA+][Br−] (85.4 %) > [BZTMA+][Cl−] (50.1 %), which is consistent with the nucleophilic ability of the halogen anion. 2.3 Influence of reaction conditions Since the [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] shows the better catalytic activity than other ionic liquids, it is employed as the benchmark to optimize the reaction conditions. The reaction temperature and CO2 pressure are fixed to be 50 °C and 0.1 MPa to optimize other two reaction parameters. With the same reaction time, the CPC yield is sharply increased from 74.2%–92.8% when the catalyst amount is increased from 5 mol% to 10 mol%. After a steady growth, the product yield reaches 99.3 % with the 15 mol% catalyst dosage (See Fig. 2 a). Within the first 3 h, there is a rapid enhancement of product yield. Then, the increasing extent is almost the same in each hour internal to achieve the maximum 99.3 % after 6 h (See Fig. 2b). The [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is solid and is difficult to be dissolved in ECH. With the generation of CPC, the reaction is accelerated since the CPC is excellent solvent for the [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−]. After the catalyst is totally dissolved, the improvement is steady with the variation of reaction time. The highest product yield is achieved after 6 h with 15 mol% catalyst amount at 50 °C under 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure. The catalyst dosage and reaction time are fixed with 15 mol% and 6 h, respectively, to investigate the influence of reaction temperature and pressure. The reaction temperature is varied from 30 °C to 50 °C with the interval of 5 °C (See Fig. 3 a). When the reaction temperature is decreased to 30 °C along with other three optimal reaction conditions, only 33.9 % product yield is achieved. With the slight enhancement of reaction temperature, the product yield is greatly improved indicating that the product yield is sensitive to the reaction temperature. If the reaction temperature is further increased, the reaction time would be shortened. The reaction temperature is increased to 60 °C, the product yield is 95.5 % within 4 h with 15 mol% catalyst dosage and 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure. When the reaction temperature is further increased to 80 °C, the product yield reaches 92.6 % within 2 h. The corresponding data are listed in Table 1. In contrast, the improvement of CO2 pressure does not arouse the great improvement of product yield (See Fig. 3b) at 30 °C. When the CO2 pressure is 0.5 MPa, the product yield is only 51.9 % that is almost the half of the highest product yield obtained at 50 °C with 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure. Perhaps there is enough CO2 in the organic phase even under the atmospheric pressure, which is captured by the ionic liquids. Thus the improved CO2 pressure would not result in the enhancement of product yield. 2.4 Recyclability and generality Under the optimal reaction conditions, the coupling reaction of CO2 with different substituted epoxides are investigated. As shown in Table 2 , the terminal epoxides are transferred into the corresponding cyclic carbonate with the satisfied yield in the presence of [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−]. When the substituted group is chloromethyl, the yield of 2c (entry 2 in Table 2) is the highest due to the substitution of active methylene. The slight decreasing yield of 2f (entry 5 in Table 2) is related with the less solubility of [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] in it. Both the large steric hindrance and strong conjugative effect of 1e (entry 4 in Table 2) and 1 g (entry 6 in Table 2) result in the lower product yields of 2e (85.2 %) and 2 g (72.7 %). The yield of 2 h (entry 7 in Table 2) is the least because of the high steric hindrance of 1 h. The products of 2b, 2c, 2d, 2e, 2f, and 2 g are characterized by 1H NMR and 13C NMR, which is plotted in the Figs. S11-S16 of the supporting information. The cycling performance of [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is studied and the corresponding result is plotted in Fig. 4 a. The carbonate yield is obviously decreased to 87.7 % after the [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is only reused for one time. It is further decreased to 79.6 % after [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is reused for the third time. The reduction of product yield could not be simply attributed to the loss of catalyst in the recovery step. The reused catalyst is determined by the 1H NMR (See Fig. 4b) and TGA measurement (See Fig. S17). As shown in Fig. 4b, the [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] has decomposed into [BZTMA+][Br−]. Since [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is not stable, the recycle ability of [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is measured. There is only slight reduction of product yield even after [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is utilized for 11 times (See Fig. 5 ). To testify the stability of [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−], the reused [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is determined by TGA and NMR. The corresponding results are plotted in the Figs. S18-S20 of the supporting information. According to the NMR result, the structure is kept for the reused [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−]. Moreover, the TGA result also indicates the stability of reused [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−]. The stability of [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is related with the strong hydrogen bond between cation and anion. One of the hydrogen bonds in the [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is formed between the protic hydrogen atom in the [DBUH+] cation and the Br-anion that is the stronger than that in [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] leading to the stability of the former. Although the catalytic activity of [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is the slightly less than that of [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−], [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is a promising candidate for the overall performance. 2.5 Mechanism and critical interactions On the basis of the above experimental results, the combination of [BZTMA+], [−O2EEPZ+], and [Br−] groups are the necessary to attain the best catalytic performance. To further confirm the contribution of each part, the mechanism of title reaction catalyzed by [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is calculated at the M06/6−311+G(2d,2p) (PCM)//B3PW91/6−31 G(d,p) level [35–40]. If the CO2 is not adsorbed by the COO− group, the ring-opening of ECH is activated by the electrophilic activation from hydrogen atom (H1) in the methyl group of [BZTMA+] along with the nucleophilic activation from Br− anion. The Br− anion is strengthened by the hydrogen atom in [-O2EEPZ+] via the hydrogen bond. Other two hydrogen atoms, H2 and H3 atoms, in [BZTMA+] group also help to activate the ECH by the hydrogen bonds between them and O atom of ECH. The barrier height is as high as 24.1 kcal mol-1, which is the rate-determining step (Route B1, See Fig. S21). If the CO2 is adsorbed by the COO− group firstly to form the complex CPB2−1, the barrier height of ring-opening step is decreased to 23.0 kcal mol-1 along with the same electrophilic and nucleophilic activation (Route B2, See Fig. 6 ). The adsorbed CO2 is favorable to push the electron towards the Br− anion leading to the stronger nucleophilic ability. Therefore, the interaction between Br− anion and carbon atom of ECH is enhanced, which is consistent with the atoms in molecule (AIM) result. As shown in Fig. S22 and Table S2, the interaction of C…Br in TSB2−1 with the Sign(λ2)ρ value of -0.05428 is the stronger than that in TSB1−1 with the Sign(λ2)ρ value of -0.05288. As to Sign(λ2)ρ values of three O⋯H interactions associated with the electrophilic activation in TSB2−1, one of them is increased and other two are decreased as compared with TSB1−1. Therefore, it is difficult to conclude that the electrophilic activation is strengthened or weakened. The decreased barrier height of TSB2−1 is mainly assigned to the stronger nucleophilic activation from Br− anion. The corresponding results would be concluded by the results of electron location function calculation. As shown in Fig. 7 , there is green colour between C atom and Br− anion in TSB1−1 (See Fig. 7a), which becomes the shallower in TSB2−1 (See Fig. 7b). Moreover, the margin between C atom and Br− anion in TSB2−1 is obscure suggesting the stronger interaction. The results related with the electrophilic activation are shown in Fig. S23, which present the similar conclusion with the AIM results. Following the above mechanism, the route catalyzed by [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is also determined except that the protic hydrogen atom in [DBUH+] cation is taken as the electrophile. The rate-determining barrier height of ring-opening step is 21.7 kcal mol-1 (Route D1, See Fig. S24). It is the slightly lower than that catalyzed by [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−], which is not consistent with its less product yield. The effect of temperature is not considered in the theoretical calculation, which is one possible reason to arouse the deviation between theoretical and experimental results. In the other side, the leaving ability of catalyst is not included in the theoretical studies along with other complicate situations. The multiple active centers, the strong electrophilic and nucleophilic activation, and the suitable leaving ability contributes the excellent catalytic activity of [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] together. Although the [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] displays the less catalytic activity than [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] at 50 °C, it is more stability and can be utilized by 11 times. Combination of various items, [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is the better choice than [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−]. To testify the above conjecture, the CO2 adsorption capacities of [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] is tested at 0 °C, 25 °C, and 50 °C, which is shown in Fig. S25. The amount of CO2 adsorption is 0.67 cm3 g-1 at 0 °C, which is the higher than the data measured at other two temperatures. The amount of CO2 adsorption by ionic liquid is much less than that by the reported porous materials. The CO2 is adsorbed by the COO− group in [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] by the interaction between them, which is different from the CO2 capture of porous materials. To design the ionic liquid with the group to trap CO2 would be beneficial to decrease the reaction pressure since the entrance of CO2 into the organic phase is accelerated. 3 Conclusion A novel ionic liquid, [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−], is synthesized to catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 and ECH. The 99.3 % product yield is achieved under atmospheric pressure at 50 °C for 6 h along with the 15 mol% catalyst amount. The excellent catalytic activity is attributed to synergistic effect of CO2 trap and electrophilic/nucleophilic activation rather than one of them. Although the [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] presents the excellent catalytic activity, it could only be reused by three times with the product yield decreased to 79.6 %. The other ionic liquid, [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−], is designed with the comparable catalytic feature. More important, it could be utilized by 11 times without slight decreasing product yield. On the basis of the DFT calculation, the reaction mechanism is elucidated along with the analysis of important interactions associated with electrophilic and nucleophilic activation. The involvement of active hydrogen atom in [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] would improve the electrophilic activation. However, it is also favorable to form the interaction with Br− anion weakening the nucleophilic activation. The suitable combination of cation and anion is the more important than the employment of only one strong group. coredata.dc:description: The efficient conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) to the valuable chemicals is of great significance but the development of robust catalyst is still an interesting and challenging issue. Four novel ionic liquids are facilely synthesized with the ability to adsorb carbon dioxide (CO2). [BZTMA+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] and [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] could catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 into cyclic carbonates under atmospheric pressure at 50 °C with 99.3 % and 97.5 % yields in the absence of co-catalyst and solvent. Moreover, the [DBUH+][−O2EEPZ+][Br−] could be reutilized by 11 times with a slightly decreased product yield. A new mechanism is proposed by the density functional theory (DFT). The excellent catalytic performance is mainly attributed to the ability of ionic liquids to adsorb CO2. After the CO2 is adsorbed, the formed intermediate would push the electrons towards the Br- anion leading to the stronger nucleophilic activation. This work introduces a new pathway to explore the ionic liquids for the chemical fixation of CO2.
coredata.dc:title: “Responsive” ionic liquids to catalyze the transformation of carbon dioxide under atmospheric pressure
